header: As we speak, the 2014 edition of YAPC::EU came and went. Already we have some blog entries reporting on the event, as well as the announcement that Granada, Spain will be where the 2015 edition will be held. Also this week, Toby Inkster goes all out in a series of blog entries revealing all the awesome secrets of Type::Tiny. Enjoy!  ~ `/anick
subject: Yet Another YAPC Properly Concluded

entries.text: At ZipRecruiter, our goal is to build the best online services for finding and filling jobs. We've grown from 4 to over 100 employees in less than 4 years with zero funding.  We care about code quality and quality of life. To learn more about our business and values, please follow the link above.
entries.title: ZipRecruiter is hiring modern Perl Programmers (Los Angeles or remote in US)

entries.text: We are a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications. We are looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
entries.title: We are Hiring a Senior Perl Software Developer - Grant Street Group
Dancer2 0.150000 has been released
entries.text: Dancer2 has a new release out, codenamed "LoonyPandora" in honor of contributor and friend James Aitken  who recently passed away. This release comes with some pretty substantial changes dealing with the main context object and the way Dancer and PSGI apps relate to each other.

entries.title: New Grant Manager
entries.text: Makoto Nozaki announces that Mark Jensen has joined  the Perl Foundation Grants Committee has a grant manager.
Sad that YAPC::EU is over? Dont' be! The Swiss Perl Workshop is happening in two weeks.
entries.title: Swiss Perl Workshop -2 Weeks

entries.text: We all know: the language is only half of the story. The other half is the vast ecosystem of add-ons, modules, plugins or packages.  David Farrell explores how the package managers of  Perl, PHP, Python, Node.js and Ruby fare against each other.
entries.title: Who has the best package manager? Part one

entries.text: The Google Summer of Code is winding down.  Talina Shrotriya gives us her last thoughts as she enters the last week of  the program.
entries.title: The last few GSoC commits (Pencils down)

entries.text: The 2014 edition of the Outreach Program for Women is now over. Pattawan gives us here her last report for it, as well as what the near future has in stock for her.
entries.title: OPW Ending for Beginning

entries.text: LÃ©on Brocard reports on the first day of YAPC::EU.
entries.title: YAPC::Europe Day 1
YAPC::Europe 2014, day 1
entries.text: Perl blogger tobez reports from the YAPC::EU front-line.

entries.title: YAPC::Europe 2014, day 2
entries.text: tobez reports on day 2 of YAPC::EU.
Leon Brocard narrates his second YAPC::EU day.
entries.title: YAPC::Europe Day 2

entries.text: Dan Muey would like not to see the ::Tiny namespace get out of hand.
entries.title: Please don't use ::Tiny unless it meets the ::Tiny criteria, thanks!
CPAN Testers: CPAN Testers Summary - July 2014 - Imaginos
entries.text: Barbie summarizes what happened in the world of Perl testing in July.
Offline testing of modules interfacing with external services  is always tricky.  Richard Elberger shares his adventures in  mocking the external components of Net::Gnats.
entries.title: Mock Testing Net::Gnats

entries.text: Yanick compares a few of the modules available to test Dancer/Dancer2 applications.
entries.title: Testing Dancer Applications

entries.text: Jeffrey Kegler talks about Marpa, and how it can deals with ambiguous grammar definitions.
entries.title: Language design: Exploiting ambiguity

entries.text: Sinan Unur released App::multiswitch last week-end, as part of CPAN Day. Later on, he realized he might have reinvented a wheel already included in File::Which's trunk. Oops.
entries.title: File::Which comes with its own 'multiwhich'
Type::Tiny Tricks #2: Types Are Objects
entries.text: Toby Inkster points out that Type::Tiny types are objects by themselves, and can be used outside of attribute definitions for, e.g., validate any value you might care for.

So you have a generic type, and one attribute is kinda of that type, but also could be coerced from a value in a special, snowflaky unique way?  Toby Inkster shows you how Type::Tiny deals with those one-off special cases.
entries.title: Type::Tiny Tricks #3: One-off Coercions
Let's talk about Time::Moment and round-trip of strings
entries.text: Christian Hansen takes a moment (haw, haw, ... okay, I'm sorry) to discuss the round-trip parsing speed of this new time module. And it's pretty darn fast.

entries.title: Perfect Hashes and faster than memcmp
entries.text: A simple hash won't do? Don't worry: Reini Urban has *perfect* hashes for you.

entries.title: Type::Tiny Tricks #4: Inlined Type Constraints
entries.text: Toby Inkster
Toby Inkster demonstrates how to have a peek on the validation of any defined type is done.
entries.title: Type::Tiny Tricks #5: Wrapping Moose/Mouse Type Constraints
Type::Tiny Tricks #6: Tricks with Tuples
entries.text: For types that are arrays of specific sizes, Type::Tiny has the concept of 'Tuples'. Toby Inkster shows how to use them.

entries.title: Type::Tiny Tricks #7: Tricks with Dicts
entries.text: Type::Tiny, this small fountain of marvels, refines the defininition of hash into two  types: maps and dictionaries. Toby Inkster shows here when and how they apply.

entries.title: How to break lines with max width? (wrap)
entries.text: Splitting a string into pieces with a max length but without breaking up words. Manually and using Text::Wrap. (article + screencast)
